SENT.plain: Pseudotumor cerebri or benign intracranial hypertension is a syndrome of raised intracranial pressure without obvious explanation
Most patients are obese women at childbearing age
Symptoms and signs usually include headache, nausea, vomiting, edema of the papilla, visual obscurations and rarely palsy of the nervus abducens
The prognosis is generally good, but progressive visual loss and eventual blindness are major risks
We report the case of a 21-year-old non-obese young woman who developed pseudotumor cerebri while taking minocycline for acne therapy
Identical symptoms occurred upon inadvert rechallenge with minocycline for the second time
